Pasteurization, the process of heating milk to high temperatures to kill bacteria, was originally introduced in the 19th century as a solution to problems caused by poor hygiene in milk production. But that was then, and today’s raw milk comes from small, family-run farms that prioritize cleanliness, animal health, and responsible handling from the farm to the consumer. These farms often operate under strict standards, and their milk is tested regularly—sometimes more frequently than pasteurized milk—for pathogens. In fact, the CDC and FDA often trace outbreaks of foodborne illness back to pasteurized products more frequently than raw milk.

Many people who struggle with lactose intolerance find that they can actually drink raw milk without issues because of these natural enzymes. That’s a powerful testament to the nutritional superiority of raw milk.

There’s also a growing body of anecdotal and emerging scientific evidence suggesting that raw milk can have health benefits, such as reducing the risk of asthma, allergies, and even type 1 diabetes in children. A study published in the journal *Clinical & Experimental Allergy* found that children who drank raw milk were less likely to suffer from asthma and allergies. That’s not just correlation—it’s a compelling reason to take raw milk seriously as a health-promoting food.

People often argue that raw milk is dangerous, but that’s based on outdated thinking and fear-mongering. The reality is that when raw milk is produced and handled properly, it’s not only safe—it’s a nutrient-rich, living food that supports human health in ways that pasteurized milk simply cannot. I’m not saying pasteurization has no role, but I am saying that in the case of high-quality raw milk, it’s not just unnecessary—it’s actually reducing the nutritional value and health benefits of a product that was meant to nourish us.

So, yes, raw milk is safer and healthier when sourced responsibly. It’s time we moved beyond the fear and embraced the truth about this natural, whole food.
